header.title: Walking Between The Worlds: TECHNIQUES OF MODERN SHAMANISM VOL.1
header.category: Western Esotericism, Occultism, Modern Shamanism, Chaos Magic

central_thesis: Phil Hine's central thesis is that 'Walking Between The Worlds' involves extending one's perceptions from the ordinary to the 'extra-ordinary' by enhancing awareness, understanding one's 'BodyMind,' developing empathy, and engaging with both people and spirits. This is achieved through practical exercises for sensory enhancement and various methods of trance induction, adapting ancient shamanic principles for personal transformation and magical work within a contemporary Western cultural context.

structure_content.summary: This section introduces the book as a collection of practical exercises aimed at enhancing awareness. It highlights the shamanic outlook's reliance on heightened perception and the ability to mediate between mundane and sacred realities. The importance of group exploration for personal growth is also stressed.

Hine contextualizes shamanism as an ancient, enduring practice and the origin of magic and religion, defining it as an 'archaic technique of ecstasy.' He describes the multi-layered shamanic world-view, including the axis mundi, the equality of all life, metamorphosis, and gateways between worlds. The chapter explores the historical origins of shamanism, linking it to the Upper Palaeolithic era and the use of psychotropic plants, and discusses its modern relevance in addressing 'future shock' and seeking reintegration into a holistic world-view.

This section sets the foundation for the practical work, emphasizing the necessity of sustained effort, community interaction, and meticulous record-keeping in a workbook. Hine outlines the core tenets of the shamanic approach: sensory enhancement, self-awareness of one's 'BodyMind,' self-understanding, empathy, and a willingness to engage with others and spirits. He also details the three distinct phases of learning for these exercises: initial enthusiasm, a 'dry' phase of inertia, and finally, a rewarding phase of recognized progress.

These exercises aim to magnify visual perception, challenging the tendency to overlook details. Techniques include 'Walking a Route' (intense observation of familiar paths), 'Kim's Game' (memory recall of objects), 'Colour Census' (awareness of a chosen colour in surroundings), 'Colour Meditation' (visualizing other senses as colours), 'Animal/Plant/Colour' (group attribution of symbolic associations), and 'Seeing Auras' (interpreting impressions as visual phenomena, noting the influence of expectation).

This chapter focuses on developing conscious listening, contrasting it with the everyday habit of screening out information. Exercises include 'Active Listening' (maintaining awareness of background noise), 'Humming Meditation' (group humming for one-pointedness), 'Sound Concentration' (repetitive verbal or silent mantra), and 'Feeling Music' (experiencing music physically and imaginatively, evoking images or smells).

Hine explores the often-undervalued sense of smell, noting its powerful evocative effect and its role as a 'hotline to memory.' He encourages deliberate attention to ambient smells and personal body odour, highlighting the subliminal communication via pheromones. Practical techniques include 'Memory/Image Association' (sniffing substances to evoke specific memories or images) and 'Building up a Smellphabet' (developing personal aromatic associations for magical or healing work).

This section delves into the perception of both 'inner' space (visualization, trance) and physical 'personal space.' It emphasizes the importance of observing and respecting varying spatial needs in social and magical interactions. Exercises include 'Blind Walks' (exploring surroundings blindfolded to sense space as an organ of perception) and references T'ai Chi as a 'BodyMind' practice for enhancing the feeling of being immersed in fluid-like space, aiding in manipulation of perceived space.

Hine highlights the voice as a potent carrier of power, linking it to 'enchantment' and magical effects in various cultures. The exercises aim to develop effective speech characterized by confidence, awareness of others, relaxation, clear thoughts, and sensitivity to situational impact. Practical methods include 'Group Chants,' 'The Spinning Mantra' (layered chanting for group trance), and 'Gibberish' (non-verbal communication through tone and inflection to convey meaning, enhancing projective vocal tools for trance induction).

This chapter examines the shaman's multi-faceted roles (trickster, healer) and the practical skill of 'status shifting.' Hine explains how status is projected through stance, tone, words, eye contact, and gestures. He provides examples of raising and lowering status in conversation ('OneUpManship') and discusses ascribed status, referencing Zen Masters and ritualistic 'fool-king' figures. The ability to disrupt cultural status conventions and project personal charisma is identified as crucial for the modern shaman, particularly in leading groups.

This extensive section covers trance states as a prerequisite for magical systems, emphasizing the cultivation and control of these states. Hine challenges conventional Western perceptions of trance as merely passive, defining it as a spectrum of altered consciousness. He outlines numerous routes to trance (dancing, drumming, fasting, sensory deprivation/overload, hyperventilating, pleasure, pain, etc.) and discusses the diverse purposes of trance: gaining knowledge, enhancing abilities (including spirit possession for healing), communal ecstasy, fostering 'connectivity' (creative leaps), and demonstrating prowess (underworld initiation). He details dream work (control, group dreams, lucid dreaming) and 'Shape-Shifting' (assuming animal/mythic forms). The chapter concludes with 'Innerworld Exploration,' describing the shaman's access via the axis mundi to mythic cosmologies and the dangers and practicalities of navigating these realms, advocating a physical, experiential approach over purely mental constructs.

Hine addresses the role of 'chemical aids' (drugs, incense, etc.) in shamanic practice, refuting the misconception that chemically-induced states are less valid or 'spiritual.' He defines a chemical aid broadly as any substance that facilitates trance, noting their physiological effects and advising practitioners to understand common street and prescribed drugs for assisting others. Crucially, he posits that all drugs have 'spirits' which can teach or challenge the user, emphasizing the need for caution, directed use, and awareness of legal implications, recounting anecdotes of misidentification and potential dangers.

This chapter frames the shamanic journey as an 'Underworld Journey' or a 'descent into the labyrinth'—a transformative cycle of 'breakthrough' rather than 'breakdown.' Hine describes it as an initiation, a conscious recognition of a developmental turning point, often involving catharsis, the relinquishing of attachments, and a 'feint at death.' He discusses the emotional challenges, such as feeling like an 'outsider,' and situates this journey within universal mythic images (e.g., the Tarot, hero's journey). He emphasizes that while guides and ritual can be helpful, the deepest initiation is internal and ultimately a solitary path of self-transformation that never truly ends.

key_concepts.definition: An enhanced awareness of one's environment and the ability to mediate between the everyday, mundane aspects of experience and the sacred, 'extra-ordinary' dimensions.
A holistic concept emphasizing the interconnectedness of the physical body and the mind, where both influence perception, abilities, and the experience of trance states.

Altered states of consciousness that are a prerequisite for magical systems, not limited to passive states, but encompassing a spectrum from daydreams to physical exertion, cultivated for knowledge, ability enhancement, communal ecstasy, connectivity, and demonstration.

Conscious manipulation and projection of one's social or magical role through changes in stance, tone of voice, vocabulary, eye contact, and gestures, essential for the shaman's multi-faceted mediation and influence.

Mythic cosmologies and planes of existence (e.g., overworld, underworld) accessed through trance, dreams, and visualization, populated by spirits, demons, and ancestors, central to shamanic exploration.

A central connecting point, symbolized as a world-tree, sky ladder, or crossroads, that links the various levels of the multi-layered universe and serves as the shaman's access point to different realms.

A conscious recognition of a turning point in one's personal development, often involving a cathartic 'descent into the labyrinth,' a stripping away of old attachments, and a period of profound self-transformation, akin to a 'feint at death'.

Any substance, including incense, psychotropics, caffeine, or alcohol, utilized to induce or facilitate trance states, understood to possess 'spirits' and requiring careful, directed application with awareness of their effects and potential dangers.

A series of practical exercises designed to heighten and refine perception through all senses (sight, sound, smell, space, speech, touch), breaking unconscious habits and extending awareness beyond ordinary limits into the 'extra-ordinary'.

A technique involving temporarily assuming the form or qualities of an animal or mythic figure through visualization or mimetic practice to gain associated abilities, explore innerworlds, or deepen trance states.

practical_system.description: Phil Hine presents a system of 'Modern Shamanism' that prioritizes practical, experiential techniques for expanding awareness, inducing altered states, and interacting with innerworlds and spirits. The system is founded on the belief that universal shamanic principles—perceptual expansion, mediation between realities—can be adapted to contemporary Western life. Its core methodology involves hands-on exercises, collaborative group work, and the holistic development of the 'BodyMind' as the primary magical instrument. Hine explicitly acknowledges the complex and fragmented nature of modern mythologies, encouraging practitioners to synthesize their own understanding through direct experience rather than adhering strictly to traditional cultural forms.

Aromatic substances (essential oils, incenses) for memory association and trance work
Tape recorder for analyzing vocal exercises (Gibberish, Chants)
Claves or other simple musical instruments for rhythm and chanting
Blindfolds for sensory deprivation and enhanced touch exercises
Group participants or a trusted partner for collaborative exercises and feedback

Trance Induction Methods (Dancing, Gazing, Gyrating, Fasting, Drumming, Sleep Deprivation, Singing, Sensory Deprivation, Chanting, Sensory Overload, Hyperventilating, Emotional Arousal, Pleasure, Pain)
Dream Work (Dream Control, Group Dreams, Lucid Dreaming)
Shape-Shifting (visualizing or miming animal/mythic forms to embody their qualities or for innerworld exploration)

Personal Initiation (a deliberate engagement with a transformative journey of self-discovery and integration)

relevant_quotes.text: 'Walking between the Worlds' requires that we learn to extend our perceptions from the ordinary, to see the extra-ordinary which lies within it.

The Shaman is one of the most ancient and one of the most enduring figures in human evolution. Shamanism is the source of both Magic and Religion, and as Mircea Eliade put it, is 'an archaic technique of ecstasy'.

As I see it, the basic essentials of the shamanic approach are: (i) Enhancement of our senses (ii) Awareness and understanding of our own BodyMind (iii) Understanding of self (iv) Empathy (v) A desire to engage with others (be they people or spirits)
It's also worth remembering that very often, we see what we expect to see, not what is actually there.
The ability to enter trance states is a prerequisite of most magical systems, particularly Shamanism.

Entering trance is not always a pleasant experience, particularly trance states involving possession. The feeling that something else is using your limbs, & that your voice is not your own, is very odd.
There's no way that you can seriously approach the practice of shamanism without at some point, looking at the role played by chemical aids - drugs.
What is a shaman but someone who's been there, and make it back again. The Underworld Journey, they call it.
The deepest level of initiation is into yourself. Someone else can act as a guide or helper, but they can't do it for you.

critical_analysis.relevance: Phil Hine's 'Walking Between The Worlds' is highly relevant for modern practitioners of Western Esotericism and Occultism, particularly those engaged with Chaos Magic and experiential forms of spirituality. It de-exoticizes shamanism, re-contextualizing its core principles—sensory enhancement, altered states, and mediation—into an accessible framework for self-development within a contemporary Western context. Hine's emphasis on direct experience, adaptability, and group work aligns perfectly with the non-dogmatic and results-oriented ethos of Chaos Magic. The text serves as a practical manual for cultivating heightened awareness and navigating innerworlds, crucial skills across various magical traditions, while explicitly acknowledging the challenges of adapting ancient practices to a 'head-oriented' and mythically fragmented modern society.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience comprises aspiring magicians, occultists, and spiritual seekers in Western cultures who are interested in practical, experiential exercises for altering consciousness, enhancing sensory perception, developing empathy, and exploring innerworlds from a shamanic perspective. It is particularly suited for individuals open to self-experimentation, group work, and a non-dogmatic approach to magic and personal transformation, including those with an existing interest in Chaos Magic, paganism, or experimental occult practices.
